title: Report: Singapore fintech startup Nium eyes US listing within 2 years
content:
“Fintech company Nium is looking to build its presence in the US as it eyes a public listing in New York in the next 18 to 24 months,” The Business Times reported.

Details:

  • The company aims to enter the US market to leverage FedNow, the US government’s instant payment service. According to a statement, Nium co-founder Prajit Nanu will personally be involved in scaling and driving the business in the country.
  • With a goal to become the next “Amazon or Microsoft,” Nium said it intends to develop organizational processes and increase hiring.

Context:

  • In a statement, the firm said it handled up to US$2.1 billion transactions in the fourth quarter of 2020 and aims to hit US$6 billion in the fourth quarter of this year.
  • A major investor in Nium is Vertex Ventures, which sits alongside the fintech firm’s other investors such as Visa, BRI Ventures, Rocket Internet, and GSR Ventures.
description: The company aims to enter the US market to leverage FedNow, the US government’s instant payment service.

title: Indonesian fintech lender Amartha bags $7.5m from Norwegian investment fund
content:
Amartha, an Indonesian peer-to-peer lending startup, has received US$7.5 million in funding from the Norwegian state-owned investment arm Norfund.

More funding details

  • Sole investor: Norfund
  • Stage: Unspecified

More company updates

  • A representative from Amartha declined to disclose the structure of the investment.
  • The company will use the money to fund loans for women micro-entrepreneurs in Indonesia’s rural areas and support environment-friendly businesses in the country.
  • Since its inception, Amartha has disbursed more than 3.7 trillion rupiah (around US$258.5 million) to more than 670,000 women in Java, Sumatra, and Sulawesi island.
  • The announcement comes after Amartha raised US$28 million from the Women’s World Banking Capital Partners II fund and MDI Ventures earlier this year.

For more coverage of the company, head here. You can also click on the link below to view key details about the company as well as its funding history.
description: Since its inception, Amartha has disbursed more than 3.7 trillion rupiah (around US$258.5 million) to more than 670,000 women micro-entrepreneurs.

title: Creator of game that allows ‘trading’ of cricket players raises $3m
content:
Imagine a cricket player as a company on a stock exchange. There’s a “stock price” for every player that can increase or decrease, depending on performance. You can use real money to buy stocks and withdraw any earnings you get from selling those stocks to your bank account.

Singapore-based Beryllium has turned this imaginary scenario into a reality with its first game, Sixer. The game, which is based on the concept of fantasy cricket in India, allows users to do “trading” on the players’ stock. There’s also a free market mode that lets people purchase stocks without using real money.

Sixer has attracted 150,000 users to date.

Amay Makhija, founder of Beryllium / Photo credit: Beryllium

Beryllium recently announced that it has raised US$3 million in a pre-series A funding led by Bullpen Capital, which counts US sports-betting firm FanDuel as one of its portfolio companies.

Genting Ventures, the investment arm of Malaysia-based conglomerate Genting Group, and existing Beryllium investor Velo Partners also participated in this round.

Founded by Amay Makhija in 2019, Beryllium focuses on integrating the trading mechanisms of fantasy sports into a game. It secured US$600,000 via a seed round in November 2019.

The startup will use the fresh funds to expand its team and engineering resources while exploring more product type, game formats, and features. Beryllium also wants to develop its headquarters in Singapore and expand its product to overseas markets.

According to Allied Market Research, the global fantasy sports market was valued at US$18.6 billion in 2019, and it’s expected to reach US$48.6 billion in 2027. American football is the most popular segment, followed by baseball, basketball, ice hockey, and cricket.

In India alone, the number of fantasy sport users has skyrocketed 50x from 2 million in 2016 to 100 million in 2020. More than 70 fantasy sports apps are available in the market.
description: The game, which is based on the concept of fantasy cricket in India, lets users “trade” on the players’ stock.

title: Vietnamese AI-powered camera maker secures G-Group backing to reach $5m valuation
content:
Hanet, a Vietnamese startup the makes AI-powered cameras for home and commercial use, said it has raised an undisclosed amount of investment from G-Group Technology. The round values the startup at US$5 million, according to a statement.

Vo Duc Tho, CEO and founder of Hanet / Photo credit: Hanet

Hanet offers cameras backed by an AI chip that enables its products to speed up analysis and help companies reduce investment costs.

Its home camera product is used for family protection while its office-centered cameras, which offer easier access controls, allow companies to automate timekeeping. Hanet also creates products that enable businesses to automate customer counting, business analysis, and theft protection.

Hanet said its products can be used for street surveillance as well – something that Vietnam currently lacks – to help solve traffic offenses, prevent child abduction, and increase overall security.

“A distinguishing feature is that [G-Group and Hanet] share a joint mission to contribute to a safer and better society through technology,” said G-Group CEO Phung Anh Tu. “G-Group will not only invest with capital but will also commit to support other synergistic values and help Hanet realize its vision.”

G-Group is Vietnamese tech major that invests mainly in three sectors: fintech, media tech, and cybersecurity. Its ecosystem currently includes 11 member companies and serves 30 million users across its platforms.

It is behind other tech platforms such as Gpay (e-wallet), Tima (peer-to-peer lending), F88 (financial services), and Gapo (social networking).
description: Hanet currently offers smart cameras for home, office, and business use.

title: The key players in Indonesia’s promising edtech industry
content:
This is the latest version of the article that was previously updated on 20 Nov 2020. Since then, we’ve added several startups and new funding rounds to the list.

||item||

Education tech or edtech has seen an explosion of interest from investors in Indonesia lately, following similar trends in India and China.

Demand for edtech solutions has increased due to the Covid-19 pandemic, and the funding momentum is also continuing. So far in 2021, multiple companies in the space – including Ruangguru, which banked US$55 million in April – have raised new rounds of investment.

In this page, we map out who the key players are, including both edtech companies and their investors. We also look at how edtech investments are trending and provide data on the funding rounds we’re aware of.

Here’s a look at how edtech funding has been going in Indonesia lately:

Here are the details on the funding rounds in the sector that we have tracked:

We hope this will be a useful, constantly updated reference for anyone who’s interested in this space.

You can also catch our coverage of the sector here, and check out more landscape reports here. We acknowledge that we’re missing some data, so do reach out to research@techinasia.com to help us fill the gaps.)
description: Education tech has seen an explosion of interest from investors in Indonesia lately.

title: Here’s how Singapore is building a tech ecosystem that extends beyond its shores
content:
Singapore has long been hailed as Asia’s own Silicon Valley. The city-state’s implementation of several bilateral and regional free trade agreements, coupled with its digital and data-friendly policies, makes it an attractive place for tech businesses.

“What attracts a lot of companies and entrepreneurs to set up shop in Singapore are our sound fundamentals,” says Ang Chin Tah, senior vice president and head of government agency Digital Industry Singapore (DISG). “There’s a lot of predictability, and businesspeople like predictability. Their businesses are hard enough to run already without having to do additional guesswork.”

Ang Chin Tah, senior vice president and head of government agency Digital Industry Singapore / Photo credit: DISG

On top of that, rival city Hong Kong has been facing political unrest in recent years, leading more companies from the tech and finance sectors to shift their headquarters to Singapore due to its neutral position amid an increasingly polarized world.

However, there are still areas that the country has to work on.

Wanted: More tech talent

According to Sam Park, who heads Nanyang Business School’s Strategy, International Business, and Entrepreneurship division, Singapore’s lack of entrepreneurial talent could pose serious concerns for its innovative future.

While acknowledging that the city-state may have “some of the world’s leading engineering schools” in National University of Singapore and Nanyang Technological University, he also thinks it’s “not enough at all” to rely on this advantage. “Tech innovations nowadays pull knowledge and resources from many different sectors. Singapore needs to be able to produce a lot more excellent talent across many different sectors,” Park explains.

DISG’s Ang echoes this sentiment, saying that it’s true that companies find it difficult to hire the right people. However, he notes that this is the case not only for Singapore but also for tech capitals the world over.

“The good and bad news of it is that there’s not enough people everywhere – even in Silicon Valley they say there’s not enough,” Ang says. “So if there’s not enough anywhere, my job in government is to capture our unfair share.”

Attracting talent by attracting businesses

Singapore’s connectedness to both developed and emerging economies puts the country in the unique position of acting as a “launchpad” for multinational corporations (MNCs) seeking to enter Southeast Asia and for regional upstarts looking to access the global market. Ang says that the city-state can capitalize on this to draw more businesses from the regional and global markets.

“The growth MNCs from the West are looking for isn’t a growth in Singapore per se, but a growth in the region,” he observes.

Ang cites Google’s Next Billion Users initiative as an example of the role that the country can play in the ambitions of MNCs aiming to capture Southeast Asia. The Google project, which is run out of Singapore, plans to create products specifically for emerging markets.

(L-R) Caesar Sengupta, vice president of product management at Google; Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, minister for trade and industry S Iswaran, and Karim Temsamani, president of Google’s APAC operations at the opening of  Google Asia Pacific’s new office at Maple Tree Business City II in 2016. / Photo credit: Koh Mui Fong / Today Online

Despite not having a billion users to offer the US tech giant, Singapore’s value is in its proximity and close ties to the countries within Google’s target market.

“Singapore is a jumping-off point,” Ang shares. “It’s a listening post for Google to better understand the needs of its next billion users.”

He adds that similarly, Southeast Asian tech players can treat Singapore as a “stepping stone” for their international endeavors. “It’s precisely because Singapore is English-speaking and cosmopolitan that they feel like it’s a great place to stretch their wings before they take flight into global markets.”

By attracting businesses from across the world, Singapore is able to create “an interesting blend of East meets West,” forming a pool of global talent to supplement the hiring needs of the growing number of businesses – both local and foreign – setting up in the city-state.

“We want to connect all these businesses and people together so that they can find partnership, employment, and mentorship opportunities,” says Ang. He points out how this would set the local tech ecosystem flywheel into motion, turning it into “a virtuous cycle of opportunities, attracting talent, which improves the ecosystem, attracting more opportunities, which attracts more talent.”

Additionally, it’s not enough to “build economic bricks” and let the ecosystem grow on its own. Only when the synergies between local and foreign companies of all sizes are harnessed in complementarity can a tech ecosystem become healthy and vibrant.

“Singaporeans around the world will start working in the labs of Dell, Google, Facebook, or PayPal, but over time, some of them will naturally osmosize into the local ecosystem,” And explains. “They’ll start their own businesses, join our universities, maybe join the government, and teach us how to better develop policies and regulations around how to fund startups, develop rules around data privacy, and think about digital economy agreements.”

Learning from global tech markets

To ensure that Singapore remains an attractive place to do business, government agencies like DISG closely follow global innovation hubs such as Silicon Valley, New York, and London. However, Ang stresses that simply copying their policies and strategies wholesale wouldn’t work; instead, it’s vital that the country learns from what these leading tech ecosystems do right and then adapt best practices for the Southeast Asian context.

We want to ensure inclusive, sustainable growth – growth that has a strong sense of social equitability.

One aspect that the Singapore government has adopted is how Silicon Valley has enabled growth without telling companies how to run their business.

“We want to be very circumspect about the role of government in developing a tech ecosystem,” says Ang. “Nobody knows better than these companies about the vagaries of their markets and the strategies they need to adopt to win – we can’t advise them on that. The role we want to play is to build a strong set of enablers, whether that’s in making sure that policies are business friendly, looking at tax rates, or looking at the education system.”

However, he also makes it clear that the answer isn’t letting the tech ecosystem “grow completely laissez-faire.”

“We can’t have that in Singapore,” Ang says. “We want to ensure inclusive, sustainable growth – growth that has a strong sense of social equitability.”

Connecting the world’s tech nodes

Though Singapore is dubbed “the region’s tech hub,” Ang says he doesn’t like to use that phrase to describe the city-state.

“If we want to be a strong tech ecosystem, we need to be connected to other nodes,” he explains. “Our vision for Singapore is to be one of many innovative tech nodes, connected to Hangzhou, Shenzhen, Bangkok, Bali, London, Tel Aviv, and other places that are coming up.”

This is a necessary endeavor because businesses and individuals “flow from place to place, as and when they need to get the job done,” Ang notes.

“We shouldn’t be building up walls or setting ourselves apart from our neighbors,” he concludes. “We need to connect with the region and the world.”

Digital Industry Singapore is a joint office of the Economic Development Board, Enterprise Singapore, and Info-communications Media Development Authority.

Learn more about Digital Industry Singapore on its website.

This content was produced by Tech in Asia Studios, which connects brands with Asia’s tech community. Learn more about partnering with Tech in Asia Studios.
description: The country is in the unique position of serving as a launchpad for global MNCs and regional upstarts alike.

title: Indonesian healthtech startup secures $3m from Telkom’s MDI Ventures
content:
Prixa, a healthtech startup based in Indonesia, has raised US$3 million in a round led by Telkom Group’s MDI Ventures and Trans-Pacific Technology Fund. Existing investors such as Siloam Hospitals Group also participated in this round.

The startup plans to use the fresh funds to scale its user base, support its business-to-business clients, and increase accessibility to more healthcare services.

Prixa CEO and founder James Roring / Photo credit: Prixa

Founded by James Roring in 2019, Prixa provides online consultation platform for health insurance owners. It also allows users to schedule meetings with doctors, request on-demand lab tests, and get medicines delivered to their home.

Prixa uses a managed care approach, which it says can help insurance companies and corporate clients reduce their claim and healthcare expenses. To date, the company has served 10 million users.

The startup has also partnered with several health insurance companies in Indonesia, such as Lippo Insurance, Mandiri Inhealth, and Generali.
description: Founded by James Roring in 2019, Prixa has served over 10 million users to date.

title: Indonesian smart-city firm raises funding from Japan’s KDDI
content:
Japanese telco KDDI announced that it has invested an undisclosed amount in Qlue, an Indonesia-based smart-city startup.

More funding details

  • Lead investor: KDDI through its Open Innovation Fund III operated by Global Brain Corporation
  • Stage: Unspecified

More company updates

  • With this investment, KDDI plans to combine its technology solution and customer base in Southeast Asia with the Qlue platform. Qlue and KDDI’s Indonesia branch have agreed to realize this plan.
  • In 2020, Qlue’s business grew by 70% compared to the previous year. Its solutions have also been used by 133 companies in 75 Indonesian cities.
  • The company has also developed QlueThermal, a solution that can detect body temperature and mask usage amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

For more coverage of the company, head here. You can also click on the link below to view key details about the company as well as its funding history.
description: In 2020, Qlue’s business grew by 70% compared to the previous year, with 133 companies using its solutions in 75 Indonesian cities.

title: Beyond the paycheck: Employee priorities have changed (Infographic)
content:
How many of you are reading this during office hours but at home?

While it was a development forced upon most people at first, remote working has sharply risen in popularity. The availability of such an option has even become a key factor that employees now keep in mind when evaluating their job satisfaction or the attractiveness of a new job opportunity.

However, it is just one of several new factors. The many social justice issues of 2020 have also changed the lens through which workers think about their careers.

Here are some insights into the latest employee priorities.

Seek, the parent company of JobStreet and JobsDB, is a diverse group of companies that have a unified purpose of helping people live more fulfilling and productive working lives and helping organizations succeed.

Find out more insights on the employment and work trends of 2021 by downloading its three-part Decoding Global Talent report series on its website.

This content was produced by Tech in Asia Studios, which connects brands with Asia’s tech community. Learn more about partnering with Tech in Asia Studios.
description: It’s no longer all about the money.

title: Meet the 100 top-funded startups and tech companies in China
content:
Which company in China is most likely to challenge the West? One way to judge – although imperfect – would be the amount of money they have raised. Using Tech in Asia’s data, we’ve generated this constantly updated list of 100 startups and tech companies in China who have raised the most money from investors.

To keep the list fresh, we’ve only included funding data from the past two years.

Seeking more? Search the most comprehensive database of tech companies in Asia or read our Research methodology. For more auto-generated lists of startup funding data, head here.
description: Here are the companies in China that are attracting tons of investors and have the resources to spend on software, talent, and expansion.

title: Chinese regulator allows Ant to begin operations of new consumer finance unit
content:
“China is allowing Jack Ma’s Ant Group to start operations at its consumer finance company, the first sign of progress after a regulatory crackdown torpedoed the fintech giant’s record listing,” Bloomberg reported.

Details:

  • The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission has sent Ant a notice, giving its finance unit the go-ahead to offer loans to individuals, issue bonds, and borrow from local financial institutions.
  • To get the unit started, the company has to shift its outstanding loans and online lending operations to Chongqing Ant Consumer Finance. Ant will take a 50% stake in the unit, which will have a registered capital of 8 billion yuan (US$1.3 billion).

Context:

  • Chongqing Ant Consumer Finance is backed by investors including Nanyang Commercial Bank, China TransInfo Technology Corp., and Contemporary Amperex Technology.
  • China’s banking regulator added that Chongqing Ant Consumer Finance needs to comply with the law and disclose all information related to its borrowers, loan terms, annual interest rates and overdue loans.
description: Registered in Chongqing, Ant’s new unit will be able to offer loans to individuals, issue bonds, and borrow from local financial institutions.

title: TikTok launches initiative to support small and medium-sized businesses in SEA
content:
TikTok, the short-video platform owned by Chinese tech titan ByteDance, has launched Shop Local Saturday, which is aimed at supporting small and medium-sized businesses in Southeast Asia throughout the month of June.

Photo credit: ByteDance

SMBs in Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam may opt into the new initiative via paid advertising packages to showcase their brand through in-app spotlight features on TikTok, which will roll out on June 4.

To help SMBs increase traffic on their sites, Shop Local Saturday will also give them with access to creators, produced ads, creative workshops and listings on TikTok’s website and blog.

Apart from its latest project, the short-video platform also offers tools and resources that SMBs can use to leverage its services. This includes an ad manager that helps create advertising campaigns with flexible budgets, a lead generation service that can convert business prospects into potential customers, and a monthly training program.

TikTok has also signed memorandums of association with the governments of Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam to conduct initiatives that will support SMBs.

This comes months after TikTok said it was looking to ramp up hiring at its Indonesia unit across areas such as category leads, logistics operation, and business development.
description: The project will provide SMBs with access to creators, produced ads, creative workshops, and listings on TikTok’s website and blog.

title: M&A deals to drive increase in exit events in next 2 years for SEA startups: Report
content:
Southeast Asia’s startup ecosystem is expected to see a total of 468 exit events between 2020 and 2022, according to a report by Golden Gate Ventures. This comes after a slump in large exit events that began in 2017 – from 153, it steadily went down to 108 in 2020.

Photo credit: Golden Gate Ventures

These exit events refer to when investors have decided to liquidate an investment in a startup either through mergers and acquisitions, secondary share sales, or stock exchange listings, which are expected to drive up such exit events.

Photo credit: Pixabay.

The spike in the number of late-stage investors, secondary buyers, and special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) have led to a positive outlook on the exit landscape for investors in Southeast Asian startups in the coming years.

Even though the pandemic slowed the pace of exits in 2020, the rise of SPACs has piqued the interest of institutional investors. Many of them are now looking at Southeast Asian tech firms and expect a strong pipeline of deals in series B- and C-stage startups.

Photo credit: Golden Gate Ventures

That said, even if SPAC mergers have become more common, these do come with a set of risks – an unsuccessful deal will leave an imprint on market sentiment and may negatively impact investor interest or a startup’s momentum.

Citing a recent EY report, Golden Gate Ventures said that more than half of startup executives from Southeast Asia are looking to actively pursue M&A deals in the next 12 months — the highest number since 2012.

Although private companies like Grab, Gojek, and Trax have made a number of acquisitions, Golden Gate Ventures anticipates further acquisition deals after these unicorns are publicly listed. This will be spurred on by an increase in liquidity from the stock market.

According to the report, this liquidity plays a crucial role in providing accessibility for companies to list themselves on Asian exchanges.

But the financing that startups receive in the stock markets after their IPO is often not a big amount, as retail investors are often “excluded.” That’s why startups have begun turning to dual listings with established exchanges.

This can be seen with JD.com’s recent listing on the Hong Kong exchange despite it already being listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).

Meanwhile, Southeast Asian companies are opting to list themselves on the NYSE as it allows direct listings with a capital raise (via SPACs), creating an alternate pathway for firms to access the public markets.

See also: The leading Asian tech players eyeing an IPO in 2021

“[The NYSE is] incredibly bullish on Southeast Asia,” said Delano Musafer, head of Asia-Pacific Capital Markets at NYSE. “For Southeast Asia tech companies, the NYSE is the more proven destination of choice, as evident by the reception of companies like Sea Group. Indeed, we expect to see several IPOs from Southeast Asian startups over the next two years.”
description: Even though the pandemic slowed the pace of exits in 2020, the rise of SPACs has piqued the interest of institutional investors in Southeast Asian tech firms.

title: How to build an MVP in Southeast Asia
content:
I don’t know about you, but I’m a perfectionist.

People like me are fixated on coming up with the most detailed plan and building multiple fail-safes, only to end up being trapped in the cycle of chasing something that’s near impossible to achieve: perfection. Some are so immobilized by the fear of failure that they don’t even begin. (As much as I hate to admit it, perfectionism is basically a glorified version of procrastination.)

This is also known as the “perfection paralysis,” and I had struggled with it for as long as I could remember.

But a few years ago, I stumbled across this quote that completely changed my perspective:

“Done is better than perfect.”

This concept is also extremely relevant in the world of startups, where developing a minimum viable product (MVP) is one of the first few crucial steps. In the early stages of a startup, a product doesn’t need to be perfect; it just needs to be good enough to convey an idea with minimal features, so that you can collect feedback and make improvements.

Building an MVP for a clear and unified audience is fairly straightforward, but what if you’re dealing with a diverse and fragmented market like Southeast Asia? How is it then different from the seemingly one-size-fits-all approach recommended by various online resources?

If you are looking to break into the Southeast Asian market and have the same question, then we have the perfect event for you. (No pun intended)

Building an MVP in Southeast Asia

Join us on June 10 and learn how to build and launch a MVP in Southeast Asia with Joel Leong, co-founder of ShopBack.

During the one-hour workshop, you’ll discover:

  • How to build an MVP to launch and scale your business in Southeast Asia
  • The differences between building an MVP in this unique region and the rest of the world
  • Tips and tricks on building an MVP for a fragmented market like Southeast Asia

About our kickass speaker

One of the co-founders of Shopback, Joel Leong currently oversees merchant development and country management. Since its launch in 2014, Shopback has grown to become the leading rewards and discovery platform in Asia Pacific, backed by investors like Temasek, SoftBank Ventures Asia, Rakuten, East Ventures, and others. Shopback has entered a new market every year on average, and it has expanded into nine markets so far, including Southeast Asia, Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan, and South Korea. For 25 million users, Shopback is their first stop before they do online shopping on Shopee, Lazada, Taobao, iHerb and Nike.

Event details

We know keynote presentations are a little passe, so we’re all about making our Live events as interactive as possible. That’s why the workshop also includes a Q&A segment where you can ask Joel anything about MVPs and the Southeast Asian market. And you won’t go home empty-handed: You’ll also get a take-home worksheet that provides a step-by-step guide on how you can plan and build your own MVP in the region.

Date: Thursday, June 10, 2021
Time: 4 p.m. to 5 p.m. SGT
Venue: Virtual

How can I sign up?

As usual, this Live workshop is complimentary for our lovely Tech in Asia Core and Live subscribers. If you’re one of us, simply RSVP here.

Not yet a subscriber? You can purchase a single ticket for US$18.90. However, you can get more value for your money by subscribing to Tech in Asia Live at just US$59 a year. We have a lot of other events in the pipeline that are specially designed to help founders like you navigate the complicated world of building a startup. As a subscriber, you’ll also be able to unlock all of our past workshops, meetups, pitch nights, and annual signature conferences.
description: Develop your own MVP in this exclusive workshop on June 10.

title: SoftBank-backed Style Theory faces lawsuit from laundry vendor
content:
Style Theory, a Singapore-based fashion rental startup backed by SoftBank Ventures Asia, is facing legal action for “continued negligence in completing its obligations” from its Indonesian vendor Beyond or PT Adhikara Bangun Abadi. The maximum estimated value of the contract between both parties is 118.97 billion rupiah (around US$8.3 million), Beyond says in a statement.

“With a heavy heart,” the vendor says it “has decided to proceed with filing a lawsuit” against Style Theory to ensure that it can fulfill its own obligations to its employees, partners, and shareholders.

Style Theory tells Tech in Asia that it is not in breach of its contract with Beyond. “Regretfully, this intended legal action does not take into account Covid-19 as a Force Majeure as stipulated in the Laundry Service Agreement and the impact the ongoing pandemic has had on many business sectors in Indonesia, including Style Theory,” CEO Chris Halim says.

He adds that the “maximum estimated value” of the contract is inflated and not based on the actual value.

Style Theory’s co-founders, Raena Lim (left) and Chris Halim / Photo credit: Style Theory

Beyond’s representative says that both companies signed the Laundry Service Agreement on July 9, 2020. The vendor had set up a laundry and dry cleaning service for Style Theory, who committed to take up a certain amount of its capacity.

The partnership was smooth at the start. But since early 2021, Style Theory has “failed to complete the payments due to all outstanding invoices,” the vendor alleges.

“They say that they need to preserve cash due to the pandemic,” a Beyond representative tells Tech in Asia.

He explained that Beyond had tried to work out an amicable solution with Style Theory, including letting the startup pay by installment. However, after agreeing to a payment schedule, Style Theory still did not fulfill its obligations. The vendor also tried to adjust the terms and conditions of the service agreement and give a discount, but Style Theory did not respond.

However, Halim said that his company has been conducting discussions with Beyond in good faith, as they figure out a solution that is fair and equitable to both parties. He added that he is not aware that those negotiations had reached an impasse.

He also declared that Style Theory has paid Beyond for all laundry and dry cleaning services delivered since the contract began. Nevertheless, the startup remains committed to working with Beyond to reach a fair agreement, Halim said.

Style Theory was founded by Halim and Raena Lim in 2016 and expanded to Indonesia a year later. Since its inception, the company has raised US$25 million, including a US$15 million series B funding round led by SoftBank Ventures Asia in December 2019. It also counts Alpha JWC Ventures and The Paradise Group among its investors.

According to data from VentureCap Insights, Style Theory made US$5.5 million and lost US$5.9 million in 2019. At that time, it had more than 200,000 registered users.

Beyond is a company that provides laundry and dry cleaning services to hotels, restaurants, and fashion retailers. Among its clients are 5-star hotels such as Grand Hyatt and Pullman.
description: Beyond alleges that Style Theory failed to fulfill its obligations, but the fashion-focused startup says it is not in breach of its contract.

title: Indian music learning startup banks funding from Inflection Point Ventures
content:
India’s Spardha, a digital platform for music and performing arts, has raised 30 million rupees (U$415,000) in a pre-series A1 round led by local angel investment platform Inflection Point Ventures.

The funding round also included participation from a few high net worth individuals based in the US, according to a statement.

Saurabh Srivastav, the founder and CEO of Spardha / Photo credit: Spardha

Founded in 2016, Spardha provides online courses taught by professional trainers to help students learn instruments and improve their vocals. It offers personalized programs that give students access to progress feedbacks, weekly assignments, and customer roadmaps for long-term development.

The startup said it will use the new funds to bolster its marketing efforts, hire for its sales and product teams, and expand into Singapore, Canada, Australia, and the UK.

According to Spardha, over the last 12 months, it has grown to have over 5,000 registered users and more than 1,300 paying customers in India and the US. The company also shared that it acquired over 500 registered users and 200 paying customers in the US within the first 10 weeks of its launch.

“[Spardha’s] future plans include expanding both the markets and the product offering to include a wider user base,” said Inflection Point Ventures co-founder Ankur Mittal. “Spardha has the potential to replicate the success of some of the leading edtech companies which have similar appeal across other verticals.”

Spardha said it’s looking at a market size of over 40 million potential students in India alone across all age groups. Globally, the company pegged the space as a “multibillion-dollar” market growing at a compound annual growth rate of 18.68%.
description: The Indian startup will use the new funds to expand into Singapore, Canada, Australia, and the UK.

title: Payments network Rapyd launches VC arm to invest in growth-stage businesses
content:
Rapyd, a fintech-as-a-service platform and payments network provider, has launched a venture capital arm to invest in early- and growth-stage businesses focused on financial services innovation.

Mastercard’s Rama Sridhar and Rapyd’s Joel Yarbrough / Photo credit: Mastercard

Called Rapyd Ventures, the new unit will work with startups that are past their seed stage and through their series B funding, according to a statement. It will also provide startups with access to Rapyd’s fintech resources and network of partners to accelerate their growth.

Rapyd said it will look for two types of projects for its venture arm: those delivering infrastructure in areas such as risk management and embedded financial services, and platforms that directly provide financial services to consumers and businesses globally.

Rapyd Ventures will be led by the company’s vice president for Asia-Pacific Joel Yarbrough, who will serve as the new arm’s managing director.

“We believe that ‘fintech’ will be built into all types of services, and we want to help bring to life a network of innovators and a rich set of new payment, identity, open banking, and embedded finance capabilities to make it happen,” Yarbrough shared.

Founded in 2016, Rapyd allows businesses and consumers to engage in local and cross-border transactions in any market through its fintech platform. It unifies global payment systems to bring together over 900 payment methods in more than 100 countries.

In 2019, the company raised US$100 million in its series C round, which was led by Oak HC/FT. Its other investors include Stripe, General Catalyst, Coatue, Tiger Global, Durable Capital, Target Global, and Tal Capital.
description: Called Rapyd Ventures, the new unit will work with startups that are past their seed stage and through their series B funding.

title: Report: Consumer behavior in Singapore, Philippines influenced the most by Western celebs
content:
Consumers in Singapore and the Philippines are influenced the most by Western celebrity and influencer endorsements compared to other Southeast Asian audiences, according to new research from iPrice Group.

Using Google data tracking major events from May 2019 to April 2021, the study showed that searches from users in both countries significantly increased for the following products after certain celebrity engagements: Crocs by Questlove and Nicki Minaj, Yeezy by Kanye West, green hair by Billie Eilish, and cryptocurrency by various personalities.

Musical director Questlove appeared on the Oscars awards show with gold Crocs in April, while singer Minaj posted a pink pair on Instagram in May. Both events triggered an increase in Google searches for the brand globally, with Singapore and the Philippines seeing an increase of more than 240%. Searches for the brand would similarly increase in both countries for every celebrity engagement, iPrice noted.

“Surprisingly, the Western celebrity style influence wasn’t as huge in other Southeast Asian countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Thailand,” said the report. “For instance, searches reached only over 37,000 in Indonesia, a country with more than 8x Singapore’s Google population.”

The footwear love continues with Yeezy, which saw a search boost of over 120% in both countries in December 2019, after Kanye West announced his new line of footwear. In December 2020, brand interest also rose by 58% in Singapore and 37% in the Philippines, following another product release from Yeezy.

Cryptocurrency also captured interest in Southeast Asia after Kanye West’s podcast with comedian Joe Rogan in 2020. This saw a 143% and 53% search increase in Singapore and the Philippines, respectively. Since then, searches blew up by 775% and 542% as of April 2021.

The higher rate of searches in the studied events are unique to Singapore and the Philippines, according to iPrice, a product meta-search platform for online shoppers in Southeast Asia.
description: Whenever Western celebrities and influencers engage with brands, expect consumers in Singapore and the Philippines to search for it on Google.

title: What does it take to be the Google Maps for enterprises?
content:
Every day, 100k+ smart people read our newsletter. You can sign up here.

Hello readers,

Have you ever been betrayed by Google Maps? It’s happened to me several times. You key in an address and count on it to show you the fastest way to your destination – but then you end up walking in circles, trying to figure out where you are and why on earth Google told you to turn left when it seems that you can only go right.

If it’s frustrating for you and me, imagine what it’s like for companies who are reliant on having accurate map data to make their businesses work. After all, how do you deliver packages efficiently when your drivers can’t figure out where they’re supposed to go? This is a concern especially in many emerging Asian countries such as Indonesia and Vietnam, where messy addresses, rural roads, and non-car modes of transportation create a situation where Google Maps may not be very helpful at all.

Today we look at,

  • How this startup wants to be the maps provider for enterprises
  • A gig marketplace that’s entered the unicorn club
  • Other newsy highlights such as Tencent getting sued and UnaBiz’s expansion to Japan.
PREMIUM SUMMARY

Who are the guys you need to know when you’ve got a place to go?

Having precise location data is critical for many of the services that, as end consumers, we often take for granted, such as food and parcel deliveries or ride-hailing. But getting a hold of reliable map data, especially in emerging markets, is no easy task – which is where NextBillion.ai wants to make a difference.

  • Part of the Grab mafia: NextBillion.ai was founded by three ex-Grabbers, who were inspired by the realization that accurate maps were difficult to come by in emerging markets such as Indonesia or India and that most businesses didn’t have the expertise and resources to customize them for their specific use cases.
  • For the enterprises: NextBillion.ai’s service, NextbillionMaps, manages and tracks large-scale geospatial data for its clients, then helps them use the information effectively in their products and services. It’s addressing a gap left by services like Google Maps, which are consumer-focused and often US-centric.
  • Wisdom of the crowd: Part of NextbillionMaps’ value proposition lies in its ability to handle the messy and informal addresses that are common in emerging markets. To do so, it leverages OpenStreetMaps, an open-sourced alternative to Google Maps, and applies artificial intelligence to satellite and street imagery to get its data.

Read more: NextBillion.ai looks to dethrone Google Maps in the enterprise space

PREMIUM SUMMARY

Welcome to the unicorn club!

Indian gig marketplace Urban Company announced that it has secured US$255 million in its latest round of funding at a valuation of US$2.1 billion, making it the latest addition to the country’s stable of unicorns.

  • Founded in 2014, Urban Company helps customers book reliable home services. Some of Urban Company’s top bookings cover salon services for women, men’s grooming, air conditioning service, and disinfection, among others.
  • Some numbers: Urban Company said it notched 1 million bookings in March, hitting its highest levels to date. Currently, the marketplace has more than 35,000 service partners across 35 cities in India, Singapore, Australia, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates.
  • The fresh funding will be used for innovation, training, product development, quality control, and safety measures for both partners and consumers.
PREMIUM SUMMARY

Unlocking the IPO process with Patrick Grove

From IPOs to SPACs, 2021 has been dominated by headlines of companies in Southeast Asia going public.

These initial public offerings are notoriously long, expensive, and complex processes. Yet this is the favored path for many founders, as graduating from the startup phase and joining the league of public companies often feels like a sense of accomplishment.

If exiting is your goal, tune in to our video series where we ask Patrick Grove, one of Southeast Asia’s pioneering tech entrepreneurs, to share his experiences in navigating the ins and outs of a traditional IPO process,

Patrick, the co-founder of companies like Catcha Group, iProperty, and Iflix, now has six IPOs under his belt across three different exchanges (New York Stock Exchange, Australian Securities Exchange, and Bursa Malaysia). He shares his experiences exclusively for Tech in Asia subscribers in our new series called Unlocked: Patrick Grove on How to IPO a Company.

Hear his advice, tips, and lessons by diving into this four-part series – we’ve unlocked the first episode! We hope you’ll learn a thing or two, be entertained, and get inspired. Happy watching!

QUICK BYTES

1️⃣ Tencent gets sued by children’s rights NGO

The Beijing-based Children’s Legal Aid and Research Center has served a public interest lawsuit against Tencent Holdings over its wildly popular Honor of Kings game, which the former alleges violates the rights of minors by encouraging addictive behavior and showing inappropriate content.

2️⃣ UnaBiz goes to Japan

Singapore-based internet of things startup UnaBiz announced the opening of an office in Tokyo as the company looks to expand into newer markets. The company will work with corporations in the country to develop solutions targeting facilities management, utilities, supply chain and logistics, and healthcare services.

3️⃣ Cainiao 🤝KOSME

Cainiao, the logistics arm of Chinese tech giant Alibaba, announced that it has agreed to become the official logistics partner of the Korea SMEs and Startups Agency (KOSME) for small and medium-sized export businesses in South Korea. Under the tie-up, Cainiao will be KOSME’s partner in its logistics subsidy program, which aims to provide up US$13,500 per company to cover roughly 70% of their export expenses, including those for ecommerce logistics.

4️⃣ Bank Jago’s SaaS partner

Gojek-backed Bank Jago, one of the earliest digital bank players in Indonesia, has selected German Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) firm Mambu to help build the bank’s technology foundation. Mambu’s main offering is a SaaS banking engine that allows clients to process banking services such as lending and deposits.

5️⃣ Tencent-backed esports major bags the bucks

Versus Programming Network (VSPN), which counts Tencent among its investors, announced that it has secured an undisclosed amount of funding from Morgan Stanley. VSPN plans to use the funds to bankroll its global expansion plans, which include producing overseas esports tournaments and developing infrastructure for a global esports ecosystem.

6️⃣ Ready, set, IPO!

Asian firms are turning to initial public offerings (IPOs) as tech stocks boom amid the pandemic, looking to strike while the iron is hot. We conducted an analysis of the startups that are reportedly planning for an IPO this year across China, India, and Southeast Asia, and we’re constantly updating it with new information – check out the latest here.
description: We dive into the startup that wants to overthrow Google Maps in the enterprise space and take a look at the newest member of India’s unicorn club.

title: Report: Yunfeng Capital-backed AI chip startup considers a $1b US listing
content:
“Chinese artificial intelligence-chip startup Horizon Robotics is considering a US initial public offering, which could raise as much as US$1 billion,” Bloomberg reported, citing sources with knowledge of the matter.

Details:

  • Horizon is currently working with advisers on a share sale that could happen by the end of the year.
  • The company, which counts Intel Capital, Hillhouse Capital, and Jack Ma’s Yunfeng Capital as its investors, is also said to be in preliminary discussions with advisors regarding a venue and the timing for the potential IPO.

Context:

  • In February 2019, Horizon Robotics secured US$600 million in a funding round led by South Korean conglomerate SK Group, memory chip manufacturer SK Hynix, and several Chinese carmaker-backed venture capital funds.
  • The company is also among a handful of Chinese players focused on developing AI chips to power surveillance cameras, autonomous vehicles, and other IoT devices.
description: Horizon is working with advisers on a share sale that could happen by the end of the year.

title: Amid the pandemic, how has tech talent relocation changed in the Asia Pacific?
content:
Like everything else in our lives, the relocation job market has been affected by the Covid-19 pandemic.

Companies usually tend to recruit from abroad when they are unable to find the right talent locally, but the pandemic has forced many businesses, including those located in the Asia-Pacific region, to put their international hiring plans on hold. Measures in place to combat the illness, such as complete lockdowns and restrictions on the entry of foreigners, are some of the reasons.

The pandemic has also greatly affected startups like our firm Relocate.me, which aims to help employers attract talent from beyond their borders. In spring 2020, most companies froze all their hiring activities, so job posting subscriptions also ceased. The market only started to revive last September.

The current state of affairs

Some countries in the region have already begun to ease entry restrictions for foreign nationals because of a shortfall in skilled workers. In Australia, for instance, 17 occupations were exempted from the immigration ban, with software engineers and developers/programmers among them.

In Singapore, companies can request entry approval from the Ministry of Manpower to bring their foreign hires and work pass holders into the country. That said, the demand for international talent from employers still hasn’t returned to pre-pandemic levels, but the number of businesses unfreezing international recruiting is steadily growing. Here’s a small selection of the Asia Pacific-based tech companies that are actively hiring foreign talent right now:

  • Australia: Linktree, Canva, and Airtasker
  • Japan: Mercari, SmartNews, PayPay, Line, Hengge, and Pretia Technologies
  • Singapore: ByteDance, BandLab, and Ninja Van
  • Thailand: Agoda and Seven Peaks Software
  • Malaysia: iPrice Group

Despite the rise of remote work and ongoing lockdowns, job seekers’ interest in gaining new work experiences abroad has also started to bounce back.

Relocation destination choices

According to our data, Australia leads the list of Asia Pacific’s most desirable tech job relocation destinations, with every second international job seeker considering it as a work abroad location. The country consistently ranks as one of the best places in the world to live and work, so this isn’t much of a surprise.

With 3,162 votes out of 7,000, New Zealand is a close second, followed by Singapore in third place.

The combination of an excellent quality of life, world-class infrastructure, a massive number of promising startups and leading technology companies, low personal income tax rates, and a very high English language proficiency level make Singapore attractive for foreign techies.

The list has remained exactly the same since the beginning of 2019, with only some internal shuffling.

The countries people are looking to leave

Among the locations that tech workers are looking to move out of in 2021, India takes the top spot on the list for the fourth year in a row. The current pandemic situation in the country and its population size are probable factors.

According to the most recent United Nations International Migration Report, 18 million Indians live outside of their country of birth. Among non-Asian countries, Nigeria (756), Russia (734), Brazil (387), Argentina (339), and the US (315) have the most significant number of international job seekers.

Changes in cross-border recruitment

  1. The transition from on-site to remote interviews

The pandemic has significantly changed the hiring process, especially the interview process. Just a year and a half ago, most final interviews with foreign candidates were on-site. Today, the interviewing process is entirely remote. A recent poll we ran showed that most international job seekers, over 70%, of the 850+ respondents were also ready to accept a tech job abroad without having an on-site interview.

  1. Remote start

Typically, companies wait until their new hires have received a work visa and only then start working with them after their relocation. Now, a new employee might begin working remotely, with the opportunity to relocate later while simultaneously completing the paperwork. That’s a definite upside not only for job searchers but also for employers, who can put the newly hired employees through their paces before aiding in their move.

  1. In-office and work-from-home days

Working from home has become the norm for office jobs. However, companies like IBM, for example, still want to see their employees work in the office X days a week. Building and maintaining an excellent company culture is easier when all team members are together in one place. It will be interesting to see what office life will look like after the pandemic is over.
description: Some countries in the region have already begun to ease entry restrictions for foreign nationals because of a shortfall in skilled workers.

title: Indonesian edtech firm that helps students attend college secures funding
content:
GoKampus, an Indonesia-based edtech startup, announced it has raised an undisclosed amount of pre-series A funding co-led by Sovereign’s Capital and Salt Ventures. Azure Ventures and some angel investors also participated in the round.

GoKampus’ co-founders Jeganathan Sethu (left) and Nathanael Santoso / Photo credit: GoKampus

Founded by Nathanael Santoso and Jeganathan Sethu in 2018, GoKampus helps students apply to hundreds of college programs just by uploading their high school transcripts. After getting accepted into one, they can then attend courses virtually, look and apply for scholarships and education loans, and find internships and jobs via the startup’s app.

The startup plans to use the fresh funds to strengthen its tech products, double its team size, and ramp up its student and university partnership acquisition efforts.

The company has more than 250,000 active students on its platform currently, with 400 university partners in Australia, Singapore, the UK, the US, and Indonesia.

Early this year, GoKampus launched Cloud University, an online university that offers on-demand courses that help students prepare for a real work environment. Participants can also get an equivalent of a bachelor’s degree after completing a course.
description: GoKampus has more than 250,000 active students on its platform and 400 university partners in Australia, Singapore, the US, the UK, and Indonesia.

title: Report: Razer eyes entry into cryptocurrency space
content:
“Razer is ‘carefully evaluating’ a potential entry into the cryptocurrency space as the phenomena gains popularity among youth and millennials,” The Business Times reported.

Details:

  • Min-Liang Tan, CEO of the global lifestyle and gaming firm, said in a presentation this week that there’s a nascent opportunity for Razer in the crypto space, given the wide reach of its Razer Fintech unit.
  • In a Twitter post, Tan also said it’s unlikely that Razer would issue its own cryptocurrency. However, he did not rule out the idea of Razer accepting cryptocurrencies for hardware and services payments.

Context:

  • If Razer’s expansion into crypto pushes through, the Singapore-based firm would be joining a number of mainstream corporations jumping on the trend, such as Elon Musk’s Tesla, DBS Bank, and custodian bank BNY Mellon. However, Musk recently announced that Tesla would stop accepting payments in bitcoin, the most widely accepted digital token.
  • The development comes after Razer announced a 10-year sustainability road map, which details the company’s goal of using 100% renewable energy by 2025 and reaching 100% carbon neutrality by 2030. However, cryptocurrency is known to have a large carbon footprint, as leaving computer rigs on for days on end is one of the main techniques for mining crypto.
description: CEO Min-Liang Tan said there’s a nascent opportunity for Razer in the space, given the wide reach of its Razer Fintech unit.

title: VC firm launches $25m fund for alternative protein startups in Southeast Asia
content:
“Good Startup, a cross-border VC firm seeking to remove animals from the global food ecosystem, has launched a US$25 million fund to invest in alternative protein startups,” reported e27. 

Details:

  • Through its Good Protein Fund I, the VC firm will invest in 32 Southeast Asian firms and assist them in areas such as IP protection, organization design, hiring, and fundraising strategies.
  • Investors including Anil Thadani (chairman of Symphony Asia Holdings), Tan Kim Seng (chairman of Kim Seng Holdings), and a consortium of angel investors participated in the financing round.

Context:

  • To date, Good Startup has invested in six firms including Eat Just, TurtleTree Labs, Avant Meats, Rebellyous Foods, Cultured Decadence, and Novel Farms.
  • The company has also bagged a VC fund management license from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.
description: Good Startup will invest in 32 Southeast Asian firms and assist them in areas such as IP protection, organization design, and hiring, among others.

title: Tech in Asia Conference 2021
content:
Tech in Asia Conference 2021 Virtual
Southeast Asia’s startup and tech scene has burst onto the global stage with headline-making SPACs, mergers, and investments. With a maturing local startup community and growing international attention, we look at how to harness the potential of Southeast Asia’s tech industry as well as address ongoing challenges.

Learn from leading founders, investors, and tech leaders across two days of power-packed content as to how they are capturing the momentum of Southeast Asia’s Global Debut.

This time, you can also finally look beyond virtual connections as we bring the buzz in-person to selected tech hubs with our crowd favourites – roundtables and networking!
description: Learn from leading founders, investors, and tech leaders across two days of power-packed content as to how they are capturing the momentum of Southeast Asia’s

title: Sources: Ant Group creates gov’t relations team for Asia expansion plans
content:
“Facing scrutiny at home, Jack Ma’s Ant Group is building a team to burnish its reputation with policy makers in the Asian markets on which its international ambitions hinge,” reported Bloomberg, citing sources.

Details:

  • Ant is hiring more people for a new division that will handle international government and foreign policy issues. Chen Leiming, the company’s senior vice president, is leading the team, which already has under 10 employees.
  • Establishing rapport with foreign government decision-makers will be the key task of the team, as Ant makes a push to expand its digital wallets and payments system in Asia.

Context:

  • Ant already has overseas investments in 10 companies across nine Asian countries, according to the Bloomberg report.
  • Back home, the company has been facing slow growth amid issues with regulators and the scrutiny faced by founder Jack Ma.
description: This new division’s goal is to establish relationships with key players in foreign governments.

title: The counterintuitive advice to make thought leadership in tech stick
content:
When it comes to establishing thought leadership for your tech company, you may want to show off your technical know-how and the intricacies of your product using buzzwords and jargon-laden content. But hot take: Nobody really cares. *Oop*

If you truly want to impress and engage with your audience, it’s not enough to just quote numbers from your extensive research.

Here are three tips to keep in mind for your thought leadership strategy.

1. Cut the buzzwords and jargon

“Our SaaS solution, which utilizes IoT, AI, and ML, will revolutionize your product and increase your customer LTV dramatically…”

When non-technical people read stuff like this, their brains shut down and lose interest. Business people use business language, and the hard data of your cutting-edge technology is hardly convincing to people beyond chief information officers.

Of course, this doesn’t mean that you should leave out the technical specifics of your product altogether.

If your technological innovation is one of your key selling points, explaining it in layman’s terms can be more powerful and effective.

Apple is a great example here. Instead of parading the iPhone 12’s “300 pixels per inch OLED screen that works without a backlight,” it simply says “OLED delivers brighter brights, darker blacks, and higher resolution for everything you look at.”

Which line are you more convinced by?

2. Focus on useful content and business outcomes

Often, it’s better to go back to basics and answer the most fundamental business question:

“How can you help me?”

Does your product help your customers save money? Work more efficiently? Or accelerate their growth? Talk about what business outcome you can achieve and tailor your proposition to your target audience’s pain points.

Here are some questions to consider:

  • Who exactly is my target audience? What are their agenda, pain points, and expectations?
  • What questions are they struggling to answer?
  • What features matter most to them?
  • How can I present my content in a creative and engaging way?

For example, human resources solutions company HReasily worked with Tech in Asia to create a series of useful and timely content for HR professionals in Southeast Asian tech startups.

Through a comprehensive survey and data-driven research, they were able to provide meaningful insights and answers to many burning questions surrounding culture-building at work, employment benefits, and online HR tools.

Branded content Tech in Asia created for HReasily. View case studies here.

Through a series of “HR in tech” videos, HReasily and Tech in Asia also shared real-life HR-related challenges and how leveraging its innovative solutions can help companies streamline its processes and build a better work culture.

Want to see how the crew here at Tech in Asia can help elevate your tech brand? View our media kit below:

3. Show, don’t tell

Master the art of storytelling and you’ll keep your customers for a long time.

When it comes to thought leadership, real-life case studies are key. When you show rather than tell the power of your product, you make your audience part of the experience and help them come to the conclusions that you want. Perhaps that’s why storytelling is one of the most powerful tools in persuasion!

For example, Southeast Asian ecommerce and gaming giant Sea Group worked with Tech in Asia on a series of behind-the-scenes content that cast light on its people and innovative ideas.

From how the company was supporting sellers amid the pandemic to real stories about its user engagement games, we used the power of storytelling to humanize Sea Group and position it as a thought leader in the regional ecommerce and gaming space.

Branded content Tech in Asia created for Sea Group. View case studies here.

Simply put, effective thought leadership involves thinking differently and presenting your innovative ideas in an understandable and engaging way. In the tech industry, it’s easy to get carried away with jargon-filled sentences which may ostracize people from non-technical roles. Instead, it’s important to truly understand your audience, speak their language, and add value to the conversation.

If your organization wants to reach the tech and startup community in Southeast Asia, Tech in Asia has the storytelling tools and loyal audience base to help you reach your goals. You can get in touch with us here or view our media kit below.
description: When establishing thought leadership, you may want to show off your technical know-how using jargon-laden content. Hot take: Nobody really cares.

title: MoneySmart posts two profitable quarters in the thick of a pandemic
content:
Singapore-based financial aggregator MoneySmart has posted two consecutive profitable quarters, according to CEO Vinod Nair, in spite of a pandemic that had battered the demand for financial products and services in the first half of last year.

The platform, which earns a commission fee from commercial banks and insurers through successful customer sign-ups, said its EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization) was positive in Q4 2020 and the first quarter of this year.

MoneySmart CEO Vinod Nair / Photo credit: MoneySmart

“Seasonally, Q4 is a high and Q1 is typically a low,” Nair tells Tech in Asia. MoneySmart was not profitable in both periods in the preceding year.

After raising significant venture capital in 2017, the company registered growing revenue and losses for three straight years. “About S$4.4 million (US$3.3 million) of costs in 2019 were due to a write-off and restructuring we did,” Nair explains. It had sold its Indonesian business to Lifepal and exited the market that year.

Since then, operating losses – measured in EBIT – have declined substantially. The firm expects them to shrink further to -S$490,000 (-US$370,000) in 2021 as it dials down on “strategic projects in insurance” to drive long-term growth.

The firm is now tracking an annualized revenue run rate of S$32 million (US$24.2 million). Between 2019 and 2020, MoneySmart’s revenue grew 23% year on year – a “modest” increase as a result of the pandemic, Nair says.

Still, this could be considered a decent showing considering the challenging year financial aggregator sites have had.

In January, GoBear, a competitor platform, announced a sudden closure amid a sharp decrease in demand for financial products, mounting costs, and a failure to raise additional capital. It has since been acquired by Australian fintech platform Finder.

Nair attributes MoneySmart’s strong showing to the company being “focused.”

“We had to make very tough trade-offs [and decide that] we were not going to focus on developing some of the smaller verticals to double down on the ones we thought could work. And thankfully, it paid off,” he says.

As demand for travel insurance took a dive, MoneySmart doubled down on products such as credit cards and personal loans – now its two largest referral categories, followed by mortgages and online brokerages, in that order.

The strategy paid off: Between Q4 2020 and the same period the previous year, revenue grew by 70%, more than making up for the shortfall experienced in travel insurance.

Growth was also a result of being able to successfully entice customers through attractive deals on the platform, Nair says. “We were able to work very closely with our bank partners to offer best-in-market deals.” These included offering AirPods Pro and Apple Watch promotions for credit card sign-ups, co-funded by MoneySmart and its partnering banks. “That really worked well to drive customer growth during a challenging time,” he says.

It is possible to get to scale and to not burn through cash.

As banks – which traditionally rely on its branches and roadshows as key customer touchpoints – struggled to adjust to a pure-digital sales channel, platforms like MoneySmart appear to have grown in prominence.

“The swing from offline to online went in our favor, so that was a fortunate outcome for us,” Nair adds.

While the firm is present in four markets, including the Philippines and Taiwan, its “main monetizing markets” are Singapore and Hong Kong, he says. Singapore is presently its largest market, contributing 75% of total revenue, though he expects the two cities to become “on par” by 2022.

Not all has been smooth sailing, however.

Company-wide pay cut

With countries closing borders and cities worldwide implementing lockdowns, travel insurance – a core revenue pillar for most financial aggregator sites – has dried up.

In the thick of the pandemic last year, MoneySmart implemented progressive salary cuts across its 120-strong team, with the highest earners taking the biggest cuts. These were partially restored in the fourth quarter of last year and have been fully reinstated as of April.

The MoneySmart team / Photo credit: MoneySmart

“We implemented a six-month performance-based restoration period [such that] if our gross profit hits a certain threshold, we’d restore the corresponding level of salary,” Nair explains. Starting in June, “increments are getting put in place,” he adds.

An upcoming focus in the second half of the year, the CEO says, will be expanding its product and service offerings in insurance.

“One of the major trends that we’ve seen is that consumers are more comfortable buying insurance through digital means,” he says. “We think this is going to be the start of a big shift.”

As travel gradually resumes, Nair expects travel insurance to come back “way stronger than ever,” with customers becoming increasingly risk-averse. Still, a World Tourism Organization survey finds that most travel experts do not expect a full recovery until 2023 at the earliest.

MoneySmart will also be working more closely with banks to develop better financial products. “If I can secure a lower interest rate through MoneySmart to offer our customers, then it’s not just about the incentive you get – you actually get a better financial product, and banks become increasingly open to such tie-ups and partnerships with us,” he says.

Contrary to popular belief, “it is possible to get to scale and to not burn through cash” despite a challenging past year, Nair says.

Currency converted from Singapore dollars to US dollars: US$1 = S$1.32.
description: MoneySmart’s milestone comes six months after GoBear first announced its closure.

title: Pakistani retail startup bags $17m from Y Combinator, others
content:
Tajir, a business-to-business marketplace startup based in Pakistan, announced that it has raised US$17 million in a new funding round led by US firm Kleiner Perkins and YC Continuity, Y Combinator’s investment arm for growth-stage startups.

AAVCF, Fatima Gobi Ventures, Flexport, Golden Gate Ventures, Liberty City Ventures, VentureSouq, and several angel investors such as Lambda School co-founder Austen Allred and Figma co-founder Dylan Field participated in the round. This also is Kleiner Perkins’ first investment in a Pakistani startup.

Photo credit: Tajir

Founded in 2019, Tajir is a marketplace that can help owners of mom and pop stores or kiranas source and buy inventory from manufacturers and wholesalers. Tajir users can also get the products delivered to their shops by the next day.

Last year, Tajir’s product was used by more than 15,000 kiranas in Pakistan.

The company was founded by siblings Ismail and Babar Khan. Because their father worked in retail distribution for fast-moving consumer goods, they learned the inefficiencies of Pakistan’s wholesale trade at young age. The brothers say that this problem still exists today, and that’s why they built Tajir.

It became the first Pakistani startup to join YC, and then it raised a US$1.8 million seed round from VentureSouq, Golden Gate Ventures, Fatima Gobi Ventures, and other investors last year. Since then, Tajir says that its platform has over 1,000 available products and its revenue has increased tenfold.
description: Tajir is a marketplace that helps store owners buy inventory and get the products delivered to their stores the next day.

title: Graph database startup ArangoDB used this deck to bank $10m in series A money
content:
||item||

ABOUT

ArangoDB is a free and open-source graph database, document store, and search engine in one. The US-based company’s services allow developers to access data more efficiently and architects to easily design, scale, and adapt their products.

Its customers include companies such as financial data provider Refinitiv, machine learning and AI firm Innoplexus, and real-time flight tracker FlightStats.

ArangoDB used this deck to secure its series A funding in 2019, banking US$10 million in the Bow Capital-led round. To date, the startup has raised roughly US$16.7 million in total funding.

Fundraising journey

  • 2015: US$2 million of seed funding from Machao Holdings and TriAgens
  • 2017: US$4.7 million of pre-series A funding led by Target Partners
  • 2019: US$10 million of series A funding led by Bow Capital, with participation of Target Partners

How is the deck compelling?

  • The deck starts by providing general information regarding the database’s development over time and its market.
  • It shows ArangoDB’s approach model and product positioning, as well as its simplicity compared to the other database platforms.
  • After introducing the startup’s key members, the deck also provides more details about the platform such as its technology, performance, and features.
  • The deck concludes by elaborating on ArangoDB’s future plans and presenting a roadmap of the product and company.
